feed.title: Review: PlayStation Vita
feed.subtitle: We check out the latest handheld offering from Playstation, the Vita.

entry.title: Review: PlayStation Vita
entry.summary: It's every bit as advanced as an iPhone, with one small disadvantage

link.Abstract: We check out the latest handheld offering from Playstation, the Vita.
link.title: [ more ]

link.Abstract: Sony Corp. Executive Deputy President Kazuo Hirai speaks about the PlayStation Vita during a Sony press event.
link.title: CES

link.Abstract: Despite being wowed by sever-al games in 2011, it's been a disappointing year, too.
link.title: Craving new breakout franchise

link.Abstract: In the world of gaming, 2011 was a disappointment, but there are still some gems worth getting.
link.title: Power Play: Best video games of 2011

link.Abstract: Sony Corp has said it is keeping to its target to sell 15 million PlayStation 3 game machines in the year to end-March, even as a long-running debt crisis grips Europe.
link.title: Sony plans to sell 15 million PS3s

link.Abstract: Sony Corp has shifted 321,400 units of the PlayStation Vita, its new handheld game device, in Japan in its first two days on sale.
link.title: Sony sells 321,000 Vitas in two days

content.div:
It's the new year and any game worth their salt was released to cash in on the pre-Christmas sales.

So yeah, it's quiet, though we do have a nice roster of big games due for release in February.

One big thing to look forward to is the PlayStation Vita.

This is the "sequel" to the PlayStation Portable (PSP), meant for gaming on the go, but as Sony will quickly remind you, it's so much more than that.

They describe it as, essentially, a smaller more portable version of a tablet device, even drawing direct comparisons to the iPad.

The main function of the Vita is games. The unit features a crystalclear screen which has touch capabilities along with the dual analog stick and traditional button control.

The innovation in this device is off the charts as there are also a couple of touch pads under the Vita, so when you're gripping the unit you can navigate around whatever you're doing using your fingers. Imagine using your smartphone with touch function on the back without having to hunt and peck with your fingers.

There are two cameras on the Vita, one forward facing and one looking away, so it can be used as a traditional camera, but also one that looks straight at you. There will be gaming applications for this, but it also makes the Vita a good vehicle for video chat via Skype or other chat programs.

The Vita also has Six-axis motion detection that allows for movement of the device to interplay with various games.

While gaming is clearly the spine of the Vita, and considering the PlayStation's gaming pedigree, the push for Sony on this is going to be around it being an "all-in-one" device.

There is a Vita music store where you can download music, there are video capabilities for watching TV and movies on the portable console. There are social apps, including a browser so you can surf the web, video and photo albums, and even a "near" device that uses a GPS and sensor to detect other Vita users in close proximity and to tie into what's in your vicinity.

I have to say, having been lucky enough to try one out, that I was struck by how light and portable the Vita is.

There's going to be no problem sliding it into a jacket pocket or into a bag and taking it wherever you want to go.

The connectivity is good as well. Much like the iPad there is a version that will hook up just via Wi-Fi, and one that will connect through a 3G network from wherever you are.

There is a compatibility with your PS3 so you can play remotely on certain titles, and that's especially handy if you have the 3GS version, so you can be hooked up to the net and to content on your PS3 wherever you can get a signal.

While I was incredibly impressed with the look, feel and functionality, the question of whether people will buy it, especially when so many have smart phones, is the $250 question (that's for the Wi-Fi version, $299 for the 3GS version).

Compare it to Nintendo's spectacular 3DS. That is a great piece of technology as well, though it doesn't have all the multimedia bullets that the Vita does, but with both traditional "portable consoles" the issue will be the price of games.

At the moment so many people are used to buying great game apps for less than $5, one wonders if they will buy into a device that is going to charge $30 or more for games.

Now there's no comparing the game experience you'll get off the Vita version of Uncharted to Angry Birds, the graphics, gameplay and value are much more impressive for the Vita.

Still, habits are what they are and if games are the big separator for the Vita, it comes down to people's desire to pay.

With the technical capabilities though, you can see more of an argument for people being able to take addictive console experiences, such as playing Call of Duty or Madden online with others around the world, on the road with them.

The Vita will give you the opportunity to do that, always connected, always able to play and always able to download.

It's saying quite something that you could have a portable device that lets you play AAA games, listen to music, watch movies, chat via Skype and connect to the Internet from the doctor's office, the No. 3 bus up Main Street or increasingly when you're on a plane if they have Wi-Fi service. And that's all for under $300.

It does seem though like the entertainment crowd is moving away from that and keeping it strictly locked on iPhones and Android clones, but the capabilities in the Vita show the portable gaming device is not going to quietly into the night.

The Vita is launching on February 22nd.

Protect yourself

OK, while devices like the Vita give you gaming on the go in a small package, I recently discovered something that lets me be a bit more mobile with my gaming but on a much grander scale.

I visited several places through the month of December where I wanted to take one of my consoles with me, be it the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360 or the Wii.

In the past that's been a bit of a problem, as they can be delicate and it's an expensive and messy mistake to either drop a console or have something dropped on it.

I got my hands on a great device called the Pelican case. These are heavy-duty plastic cases that are secure, waterproof and very portable. You can lock them up with padlocks, some versions have wheels and handles so you can even go on a trip through mass transit (spring break trip, or a cruise) and bring your console with you and have it be safe and secure.

Inside is foam, which you can cut out to fit your device. They are billing some of their models (the 1500 and 1600) as gaming cases but they really work for anything you need to transport securely, cameras, laptops, gaming consoles.

I love having the ability to take my PS3 on the go with me either for to watch movies or play games away from home, they may not be for everyone, but they're not that expensive, many of the models are under $200 and versus a damaged console, they've been a good find for me to be able to keep gaming even when I'm not at home.

Twitter: @paulc14

link.Abstract: Sony’s PlayStation Vita game console is now on sale in Japan.
link.title: Sony’s upcoming PlayStation Vita game console will go on sale by the end of this year in Japan, followed by releases in the U.S. and European markets in early 2012 said Kazuo Hirai, executive vice president.

link.Abstract: Sony's upcoming PlayStation Vita game console will not hit shops in North America and Europe until after the key Christmas holiday shopping season, the Japanese company said Thursday.
